awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Accelerating the Discovery of Electronic Materials through Human-Computer Active Search
awd_abstract_narration:
The overarching goal of this project is to accelerate the discovery of  materials with tailored electronic properties through human-computer active search. These efforts will lay the groundwork for accelerating materials discovery, and advance the capability to control electronic properties in materials with the potential for profound societal impact. The thermoelectric and photocatalytic materials predicted, synthesized, and characterized in this research can realize societal advances in the space of energy and solar fuels. High-efficiency thermoelectric materials can revolutionize how heat sources are transformed into electrical power by eliminating the traditional intermediate mechanical energy conversions.  Earth-abundant  light-responsive catalysts are emerging as  an alternative to costly, rare metal catalysts to store solar energy as  portable liquid fuels, like ethanol. These green reactions  are enabling low-cost, carbon-neutral fuels.  The team brings together expertise in materials science, chemistry, machine learning, visualization, metadata, and knowledge frameworks to develop multi-fidelity, expert-guided active search strategies within materials science and chemistry.  Resonances among the team's existing outreach programs will broaden inclusion of students from underrepresented groups and be moderated via the Alliance for Diversity in Science and Engineering.  The work will provide cross-disciplinary training to graduate students and postdocs in all aspects of material informatics, including participating in and leading team efforts, co-mentorship of Ph.D.  and postdoctoral researchers, inclusive symposia at national conferences, and a summer workshop focused on the intersection of visualization, machine learning, ontological engineering and materials science. Through enabling the acceleration of the discovery of new materials, this project supports the goals of the Materials Genome Initiative. 

An interdisciplinary team will create a search framework for scientific discovery that leverages recent advances in material databases, machine learning, visualization, human-machine interaction, and knowledge structures. To broadly assess the efficacy of this approach, the search effort will span the electronic behavior of both molecules and crystalline materials:  (i) new organic photocatalysts for solar fuels production and (ii) new thermoelectric materials for electricity generation.  Central to this effort is the engagement of domain experts and associated feedback in a human-in-the-loop active search process. Dynamic visualizations will enable the user to (i) understand the underlying reasons why the materials are being suggested and (ii) provide a user steering capability to identify and annotate specific aspects of the explored search space. Domain-expert annotations and feedback will be parsed against a suite of ontologies, further aiding the search process by providing relational insight between features. New molecules and materials will be explored through a combination of first principles calculations and high-throughput, automated experimentation; these results will be incorporated into a continually growing open-access database. Efficiently integrating and directing evolving data-streams from experiment, computation, and human steering during the search will be achieved with a multi-fidelity active search policy. Through enabling the acceleration of the discovery of new materials, this project supports the goals of the Materials Genome Initiative.  

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity, and is jointly supported by HDR and the Division of Materials Research within the NSF Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This interdisciplinary project investigated the use of Bayesian experimental design for accelerating materials discovery, specifically materials with favorable electronic properties. Our effort on this project entailed contributions to both foundational methodology for Bayesian experimental design as well as specific applications to materials discovery in collaboration with fellow project members.

Our contributions primarily focused on the paradigm of "active search," a mathematical formalization of a pervasive scientific discovery setting. Here we are faced with a design space of possible configurations of some system we may investigate at high cost, e.g., via expensive simulation or experiment. Hidden among this space are novel structures exhibiting desirable properties (according to conditions defined by the investigator) we seek to find, and budget constraints preclude exhaustive search of the entire space.  The goal of active search is then to adaptively design a sequence of experiments so as to maximize the number of discoveries under a limited budget.

To this end, we developed algorithms enabling the use of active search in important settings where it was not previously possible. The first of these settings was the "multifidelity" case, where the investigator has access to multiple methods for measuring properties in the design space with varying cost and fidelity. This is often the case in modern materials science, where we may augment traditional laboratory experiments (high cost/fidelity) with computer simulation (lower cost/fidelity). We developed a holistic active search method that can intelligently leverage access to both types of information for cost-effective discovery. Another notable setting was the "multiclass" case, where the investigator may wish to discover multiple types of structures in a single experimental campaign. We developed an active search method that can handle this multiclass case in a nuanced way, including reasoning about tradeoffs between different types of discoveries and the ability to encourage diversity in discovery.

We also developed novel methodology for the highly related setting of nonmyopic Bayesian optimization, a family of algorithms seeking to optimize an expensive objective function (e.g., material properties of interest) over a design space.  These techniques have made great headroom in accelerating a wide range of materials discovery settings over the past 5-10 years. The algorithms we developed during this project improve optimization efficiency and could support future materials discovery efforts.

The team also participated in a focused collaborations with materials science and visualization partners on the project. The first was an effort to apply active search to accelerate the discovery of visible light-activated azoarene photoswitches with long half-lives, a family of molecules that have many potential uses including pharmacology and catalysis. This was a highly interdisciplinary effort, and the results were quite promising: active search was able to accelerate the discovery of these molecules by approximately 3x compared to random search. Another component of this effort was to use visualization techniques to effectively communicate about the results of the search procedure with domain experts. Our second collaboration was on an investigation into using statistical methods to efficiently simulate properties of high-entropy alloys, which could be used in future investigations to accelerate discovery in such spaces.

Work from this project was published and presented at international machine learning conferences (AISTATS 2023, ICML 2021, ICML 2020) as well as in materials science journals (Journal of Chemical Information and Modeling, Physical Review Materials). The work was also presented at the Materials Research Society meeting in Fall 2023.

 


Last Modified: 02/08/2024
Modified by: Roman Garnett
